text:
In a piece called “No More Yes. It’s Either HELL YEAH! Or No,”

Derek Sivers describes a simple technique for making choices.

The key is to put the decision to an extreme test.

If we feel total conviction to do something, we say yes.

Anything less gets a thumbs down.

A leader at Twitter said, "If the answer isn’t a definite yes, then it should be a no."

This is a succinct summary of a core Essentialist principle.

It is critical to the process of exploration.

Derek lives this principle himself.

When he wasn’t impressed by job candidates, he said no to all.

Eventually, he found the right person.

He signed up for conferences he wasn’t excited about.

He decided to stay home and skip them.

He earned twelve days to use for more productive ends.

When deciding where to live, he ruled out good places.

He visited New York and knew it was the right place.

Think back to our closets and the broad criterion.

“Is there a chance that I will wear this someday?”

The closet becomes cluttered with rarely worn clothes.

If we ask, “Do I absolutely love this?” we can eliminate clutter.

We will have space for something better.

We can do the same with other areas of our lives.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Using extreme criteria for decision-making helps prioritize what truly matters and eliminate unnecessary clutter in our lives.
